Topic.Title: Some earnings insights

Message.Msg: jcosurvey: Excellent point. By converting from (I am assuming operating) lease to ownership, you replace a rental payment (which constitutes depreciation and interest payments) all subtracted from operating income into (if debt finance building) depreciation (operating item) and interest expense. You can roughly guess that this will boost operating profit (relative to old standard) by around 1% x $1.2 billion since the interest expense on their bond issues was really low (.9% to low 1%). That's $12 billion but last quarter would have only been around $1.5 million given timing of purchase (late November)

Message.Title: Cramer and his famous column
Message.Msg: The Winners of the New World This is the column he wrote just before the Nasdaq 5000 crash February 29 of 2000. What is so funny is 13 years ago he was saying the same BS about AMZN that the longs keep still saying today but nothing has changed- "it will be done with its buildout and will effectively be able to cherry-pick whomever it wants to destroy while having it be subsidized by other areas. It will be Home Depot (HD_) vs. Wal-Mart vs. Amazon in the end." All the stocks he recommended at the top wow. Bunch of them went bankrupt like svnx, others crashed 90% like insp. "How did this bizarro world where nine-tenths of the companies I have followed as a stock picker for the last 20 years are losers and one-tenth are winners? To answer that question, you have to throw out all of the matrices and formulas and texts that existed before the Web. You have to throw them away because they can't make money for you anymore, and that is all that matters. We don't use price-to-earnings multiples anymore at Cramer Berkowitz. If we talk about price-to-book, we have already gone astray. If we use any of what Graham and Dodd teach us, we wouldn't have a dime under management. Fourth, it just destroys retail as we know it. Why? Because the companies that embrace the Web more vigorously will eventually be pitted against other companies that embrace the Web more vigorously, creating a virtual constant price war, the kind of war that Marx, of all, actually predicted would happen to capitalism. It will happen to retail once everyone realizes that Amazon (AMZN_) recreated Wal-Mart (WMT_) online because it will forever have access to cheap capital. Why do I say forever? Because at a certain point, it will be done with its buildout and will effectively be able to cherry-pick whomever it wants to destroy while having it be subsidized by other areas. It will be Home Depot (HD_) vs. Wal-Mart vs. Amazon in the end. Nobody else. And that's only if Home Depot figures out it better get on the Web and fast. "

Topic.Title: RETAIL SHOULD DEPLOY LEAP PUTS TOMORROW ON ANY SCAM PUMP BY FRAUD STREET ON SCAMAZON

Message.Msg: I am trying to get my hands around all the fulfillment costs they say are being expended expanding the # of centers they have. Many of these are capital expenses not periodic expenses. So why use this excuse. They will have fixed costs and variable costs with these centers. In my experience variable costs tend to be more fixed in nature short term and fixed costs are only variable in the long term. So people that are expecting big drops in expenses going forward are not forecasting correctly. Depreciation for one example will be fixed for a period likely equaling depreciation life of 31.5 years (tax depreciation) and labor costs will only go up over time. Maybe with higher utilization they drop in % of sales terms with more effeciency but still why are people paying a high price for a model that seems to be getting more brick/morter. Another thing that bothers me is their segment reporting. Auditors should be examining this more closely. Now they have domestic and int'l as their segments. They should have segments including AWS, retail, and third party fulfillment. Need this information in order to better model the company's prospects. And with no commentary by Bezos on the conference call nobody can tell what the hell is going on with this company. All grey areas.

Topic.Title: The bull case

Message.Msg: Kenji: Amazon ran short of cash in its best cash generating quarter. The quant/algos need buybacks to frontun. Amazon lacks the cash to do buybacks in 2013 (or will cease to invest and thus show its "hypergrowth" is done...). It needs to be punished to generate some cash for buybacks so the front running machines can eat.... without cash for buybacks (which would be absurd at these valuations anyway), the dilution becomes more of an issue. And then the self reinforcing vicious cycle takes over. Then the are the fundamentals and the looming PR issues (as BestBuy and others prove amazon was misleading on the impact of sales tax -- the CFO always carefully worded his answer to say Amazon sells a lot in areas that collect tax, rather than Amazon has the same sales intensity...). I can and will tear all of the half truths to shreds. This never shoukd have hit $200 let alone $290 AH. Unless and until institutional longs kill the momentum bubble scams,retail will not return. They've been trying for months. It ain't working, despite CNBC's attempt to frame the institutional squeezes as retail rotation...
